name: Corn
title: How to Plant Corn
overview: Sweet corn is a warm-season annual. Sow in blocks for good pollination and keep evenly watered.
steps: Pick a full-sun site with fertile, well-drained soil (pH 6.0–6.8).
Amend soil with compost; rake into 30–36 in (75–90 cm) rows.
Direct-sow seeds 1–1.5 in deep, 8–10 in apart; plant in at least 3 short rows (a block).
Keep soil consistently moist; mulch to retain water.
Side-dress with nitrogen when plants are 12 in tall and again at tasseling.
Weed carefully; avoid disturbing shallow roots.
Harvest when silks brown and kernels exude milky juice (about 18–24 days after silking).
Cool ears immediately after picking for best sweetness.

name: Wheat
title: How to Grow Wheat
overview: Winter wheat is sown in fall and harvested the following summer.
steps: Choose a full-sun field with well-drained loam.
Till and level, then broadcast seed at recommended rate (~90–120 lbs/acre) or drill 1–1.5 in deep.
Irrigate lightly to establish; avoid waterlogging.
Fertilize based on soil test; add nitrogen at tillering and again at jointing.
Scout for rusts/aphids; treat if thresholds are exceeded.
Reduce weeds with early canopy and mechanical control.
Harvest when heads are golden and kernels hard (~13–15% moisture).
Dry/clean grain and store in a cool, dry place.

name: Tomatoes
title: How to Grow Roma Tomatoes
overview: Tomatoes love heat and steady moisture; stake early for tidy plants.
steps: Start with disease-resistant seedlings; harden off before transplanting.
Plant in full sun after frost; space 18–24 in apart.
Bury stems deep to encourage roots; add compost and slow-release fertilizer.
Install stakes/cages immediately; tie as they grow.
Water at soil level 1–1.5 in/week; mulch to prevent splash.
Prune lower leaves; remove suckers if desired.
Feed with balanced fertilizer at first fruit set.
Harvest when fruits are deep red and firm; avoid refrigeration for flavor.

name: Rice
title: How to Plant Rice
overview: General steps for starting, caring, and harvesting a healthy crop.
steps: Select a full-sun site with well-drained soil; amend with compost.
Plant at recommended spacing/depth for the crop.
Irrigate consistently; mulch to conserve moisture and suppress weeds.
Fertilize based on soil test and crop needs.
Scout for pests/diseases weekly; act only if thresholds are exceeded.
Keep the bed weed-free during early growth.
Harvest at proper maturity; handle gently; store appropriately.

overview: General steps for starting, caring, and harvesting a healthy crop.
steps: Select a full-sun site with well-drained soil; amend with compost.

Scout for pests/diseases weekly; act only if thresholds are exceeded.
Keep the bed weed-free during early growth.
Harvest at proper maturity; handle gently; store appropriately.

name: Cucumber
title: How to Grow Cucumbers
overview: A vining annual that needs warmth, rich soil, and plenty of water; supports are recommended.
steps: Direct-sow seeds $\frac{1}{2}$ in deep after all danger of frost is past; or use transplants.
Plant in full sun, 12–18 in apart; provide a trellis or cage.
Amend soil heavily with compost and manure; side-dress every 3–4 weeks.
Water consistently and deeply at the base to prevent bitterness.
Hand-pick cucumber beetles and scout for powdery mildew.
Harvest when fruits are deep green, firm, and before they turn yellow (usually 50–70 days).

name: Spinach
title: How to Grow Spinach
overview: A cool-season crop that quickly "bolts" (goes to seed) in heat; plant early.
steps: Direct-sow seeds $\frac{1}{2}$ in deep, 1–2 in apart, as soon as soil can be worked in spring or late summer.
Choose a partial shade location in warmer weather; full sun in cool weather.
Keep soil moist and fertile; side-dress with nitrogen after first cutting.
Use row covers to protect from leaf miners in spring.
Harvest outer leaves when they are large enough to eat, or cut the whole plant before bolting.
Mulch helps keep the roots cool and moist.

name: Peppers
title: How to Grow Bell Peppers
overview: Require a long, hot growing season; start indoors early and protect from cold.
steps: Start seeds indoors 8–10 weeks before last frost; use heat mats for best germination.
Harden off seedlings and transplant into full sun when night temps are above $55^{\circ}\text{F}$ ($13^{\circ}\text{C}$).
Space 18–24 in apart; use cages or stakes to support heavy fruit loads.
Water evenly and deeply; avoid overhead watering.
Fertilize with a balanced formula until flowering, then switch to low nitrogen/high phosphorus.
Harvest when firm and fully colored (green, red, yellow, etc.); a gentle twist releases the fruit.

name: Oats
title: How to Grow Oats
overview: A cool-season grain grown primarily for its edible seed; tolerant of poor soils.
steps: Sow as early as the ground can be worked in spring, typically 1–2 in deep.
Broadcast or drill seed at the recommended rate (e.g., 60–100 lbs/acre).
Prefers full sun and well-drained soil, but is tolerant of heavy soils.
Fertilize with nitrogen based on soil test, usually less than wheat requires.
Scout for common diseases like rusts; ensure good field drainage.
Harvest when grains are firm and the tops of the plants have turned a golden-yellow (mid-summer).

name: Garlic
title: How to Plant Garlic
overview: Plant in the fall to harvest in the summer; requires a cold period for bulb formation.
steps: Break apart bulbs; plant individual cloves, pointy-side up, 2 in deep and 6 in apart, in late fall (Oct/Nov).
Choose a full-sun site with very loose, rich, well-drained soil.
Mulch heavily with straw (4–6 in) immediately after planting for winter protection.
Water during dry spells in spring; stop watering once leaves start to yellow in early summer.
Remove scapes (flower stalks) on hardneck varieties in late spring to redirect energy to the bulb.
Harvest when the lower third of the leaves are brown and two-thirds are still green.

name: Broccoli
title: How to Grow Broccoli
overview: A cool-season vegetable needing consistent moisture and plenty of nitrogen.
steps: Start seeds indoors 5–6 weeks before the last frost; or sow mid-to-late summer for a fall crop.
Transplant into rich, full-sun soil, spacing 18–24 in apart.
Side-dress with high-nitrogen fertilizer 3 weeks after transplanting.
Keep soil constantly moist; use mulch to keep roots cool.
Use row covers to protect from cabbage worms and flea beetles.
Harvest the main head when tight and firm before the flower buds begin to open (turn yellow).
Side shoots will often grow after the main head is cut.

name: Sweet Potato
title: How to Plant Sweet Potatoes
overview: Needs a long, hot growing season and rich, well-drained soil; planted from "slips."
steps: Plant "slips" (sprouts) 12–18 in apart in well-drained, mounded rows after the soil is warm (min $60^{\circ}\text{F}$/$16^{\circ}\text{C}$).
Choose a full-sun site; amend soil with compost, but avoid fresh manure/high nitrogen.
Water consistently for the first few weeks, then reduce watering later in the season.
Hilling or mounding is often done to increase soil warmth and drainage.
Weed shallowly to avoid disturbing the developing roots.
Harvest before the first hard frost, typically 90–120 days after planting slips.

name: Lentils
title: How to Grow Lentils
overview: A cool-season legume that fixes nitrogen; sensitive to heat and moisture extremes.
steps: Direct-sow $\frac{1}{2}$–1 in deep in early spring, spacing 3–6 in apart.
Choose a full-sun site with loose, well-drained, slightly acidic soil.
Do not apply nitrogen fertilizer; use a phosphorus/potassium-based one if needed.
Require little water after establishment, but irrigate during flowering if rainfall is low.
Control weeds early; dense planting can help suppress later weed growth.
Harvest when the lower pods are dry and rattling, but before they shatter (split open).

name: Blueberries
title: How to Grow Blueberries
overview: A perennial shrub needing very acidic soil and cross-pollination; takes years to fully produce.
steps: Select a full-sun site and amend soil heavily to reach a low pH (4.5–5.5); use peat moss or sulfur.
Plant two or more different varieties for best cross-pollination and yield.
Plant dormant bare-root or potted plants 4–6 ft apart in early spring.
Mulch heavily with pine needles or sawdust to maintain acidity and moisture.
Prune to remove old, woody canes in late winter/early spring.
Water with rainwater or acidic water; avoid chlorinated/hard tap water.
Harvest when the berries are fully blue and drop easily into your hand.

name: Cabbage
title: How to Grow Cabbage
overview: A cool-season crop that needs consistent moisture and a rich, deep soil.
steps: Start seeds indoors 6–8 weeks before last expected frost; or sow mid-summer for fall harvest.
Transplant into full sun (or partial shade in heat), spacing 12–24 in apart.
Amend soil with plenty of compost; side-dress with nitrogen when the head begins to form.
Keep soil constantly moist; inconsistent water can cause heads to split.
Cover with row covers to deter cabbage moths and worms.
Harvest when the head is solid, firm, and fully sized; cut the stem at the base.

name: Zucchini
title: How to Grow Zucchini
overview: A prolific, fast-growing squash requiring full sun and consistent water; often harvested when young.
steps: Direct-sow 2 seeds 1 in deep after last frost; thin to the strongest seedling.
Plant in hills 3-4 ft apart in rich, well-composted soil.
Water deeply and consistently, especially during flowering and fruiting.
Hand-pollinate if early fruit is dropping; scout for squash vine borer and powdery mildew.
Harvest when 6–8 inches long and skin is shiny; check daily during peak season.
Mulch heavily to retain moisture and suppress weeds.

name: Cabbage
title: How to Grow Cabbage
overview: Needs a long, cool period to form a tight, solid head; high water and nitrogen needs.
steps: Start indoors 6-8 weeks before last frost or in mid-summer for fall.
Plant 12–24 in apart in deeply prepared, fertile soil with a pH of 6.0-6.5.
Side-dress with high-nitrogen fertilizer when plants are 6 in tall and again when heads begin to form.
Keep soil consistently moist; uneven watering can cause the head to split.
Cover plants to deter cabbage worms; rotate crops annually.
Harvest when the head is very firm and solid; cut the stem close to the ground.

name: Sunflowers
title: How to Grow Sunflowers
overview: Tall, drought-tolerant plants grown for seeds, oil, or ornamental value; needs lots of sun.
steps: Direct-sow seeds $\frac{1}{2}$–1 in deep and 12–36 in apart after the last spring frost.
Choose a full-sun site with average, well-drained soil.
Water deeply until well established, then only during severe drought.
Stake tall varieties in windy areas; fertilize sparingly.
Protect maturing seed heads from birds (e.g., netting).
Harvest when the back of the head turns yellow-brown and the seeds are plump and dry.

name: Kidney Beans
title: How to Grow Kidney Beans
overview: Bush varieties are easy to grow; nitrogen-fixing and prefer warm soil.
steps: Direct-sow 1 in deep after the soil has warmed and all danger of frost is past.
Plant 4-6 in apart in rows 2-3 ft apart in full sun.
Does not require trellising (bush type); water regularly, especially during flowering.
Do not over-fertilize with nitrogen; they produce their own.
Avoid disturbing foliage when wet to prevent fungal diseases.
Harvest when the pods are dry, brittle, and the seeds inside are hard and rattling.

name: Beets
title: How to Grow Beets
overview: Cool-season root vegetable grown for both their root and edible tops; needs loose soil.
steps: Direct-sow $\frac{1}{2}$ in deep, 2–3 in apart, in early spring or late summer.
Choose a full-sun site with loose, fertile, stone-free soil (pH 6.0–7.0).
Thin seedlings when 2 in tall; eat the thinnings as greens.
Water consistently to prevent the roots from becoming woody.
Side-dress with phosphorus and potassium, as they are heavy feeders.
Harvest roots when they reach the desired size (usually 1.5-3 in diameter).

name: Sweet Pea
title: How to Grow Peas
overview: A cool-season crop that needs support; plant early and protect from heat.
steps: Direct-sow 1 in deep, 2 in apart, as soon as the soil can be worked in spring.
Plant in full sun and provide a trellis or netting immediately for climbing vines.
Keep well-watered, especially once flowering begins.
Avoid high-nitrogen fertilizer; amend with compost before planting.
Mulch heavily to keep roots cool and moist.
Harvest when the pods are plump and firm but before the peas get hard (usually 60–70 days).

name: Pumpkin
title: How to Grow Pumpkins
overview: A sprawling vine that requires a lot of space, rich soil, and a long growing season.
steps: Direct-sow 1 in deep in hills 5–10 ft apart after the last spring frost.
Plant in a full-sun location with extremely rich, well-drained soil.
Water deeply and regularly, aiming water at the base of the plant.
Fertilize regularly with a balanced feed until flowering, then a high-potassium/phosphorus feed.
Prune vines to 1-2 fruits per vine for larger sizing.
Harvest when the rind is hard and deep orange and the stem is dry and woody.

name: Kale
title: How to Grow Kale
overview: A hardy leafy green that tolerates frost well and can be harvested throughout the winter in mild climates.
steps: Start indoors 4-6 weeks before last frost or direct-sow in early fall.
Plant 12–18 in apart in full sun to partial shade; prefers slightly acidic soil (pH 6.0-7.0).
Water consistently; it thrives in moist soil.
Side-dress with nitrogen every 4-6 weeks for continuous leaf growth.
Protect from cabbage moths (use row covers) and aphids.
Harvest by picking the oldest, outer leaves first, leaving the center bud intact.

name: Leeks
title: How to Grow Leeks
overview: A slow-growing, cold-tolerant relative of the onion grown for its edible white stalk.
steps: Start seeds indoors 8-10 weeks before the last frost or buy transplants.
Plant 6 in deep in trenches; gradually fill the trench to "blanch" (whiten) the stems as they grow.
Plant in a full-sun site with very rich, loose, well-drained soil.
Keep consistently moist; do not allow the soil to dry out.
Fertilize monthly with a balanced feed, but not excessively high in nitrogen.
Harvest when they reach the desired size, usually the diameter of a quarter or more.

name: Mint
title: How to Grow Mint
overview: A vigorously spreading perennial herb; best grown in containers to prevent invasiveness.
steps: Plant potted plants or root cuttings in spring or fall.
Plant in a container or a confined area, as it spreads aggressively via runners.
Prefers partial shade but will tolerate full sun with adequate moisture.
Water regularly to keep the soil moist.
Fertilize sparingly, if at all; high fertility reduces oil content/flavor.
Prune aggressively to promote fresh new growth and prevent flowering.
Harvest leaves any time, but best just before flowering for peak oil content.

name: Eggplant
title: How to Grow Eggplant
overview: A heat-loving vegetable; treat similar to tomatoes and peppers.
steps: Start seeds indoors 8–10 weeks before last frost; needs warm soil to germinate.
Transplant after soil is warm (min $60^{\circ}\text{F}$/$16^{\circ}\text{C}$) and night temperatures are consistently warm.
Plant 24–30 in apart in full sun; needs rich, well-drained soil.
Stake or cage plants to support heavy fruit.
Water consistently and mulch heavily to maintain moisture.
Fertilize regularly with a balanced feed throughout the season.
Harvest when the skin is firm and shiny; cut the stem with clippers (do not pull).

name: Asparagus
title: How to Grow Asparagus
overview: A long-lived perennial vegetable that can produce for 15-20 years; plant in spring.
steps: Dig a deep trench (8-10 in); plant 1-year-old crowns 15-18 in apart, spreading roots out.
Gradually fill the trench with soil as the spears grow taller over the first year.
Plant in a dedicated, full-sun spot with very well-drained, deeply amended soil.
Keep the area weed-free; do not harvest the first 2-3 years to establish the crown.
Fertilize in early spring and again after the cutting season ends.
Harvest spears 6-8 in tall and $\frac{1}{2}$ in thick by snapping them off at ground level.

name: Hops
title: How to Grow Hops
overview: A climbing perennial vine (bine) grown for its cones (flowers) used in brewing.
steps: Plant rhizomes (root cuttings) in early spring after the last frost.
Plant in full sun with rich, well-drained soil; space 3-5 ft apart.
Requires a strong trellis or support system (coir/twine) at least 15-20 ft tall.
Water deeply, especially during the first year of establishment.
Fertilize heavily with nitrogen in early spring and again in mid-summer.
Harvest cones when they are springy, papery, and fragrant (usually late August/early September).

name: Raspberries
title: How to Grow Raspberries
overview: A perennial shrub that spreads by suckers; requires trellising and yearly pruning.
steps: Plant dormant bare-root canes in early spring, 2-3 ft apart in rows 6-8 ft apart.
Choose a full-sun site with deep, well-drained, slightly acidic soil.
Install a support system (trellis/posts) immediately after planting.
Water consistently and deeply, especially when fruit is developing.
Prune dead or old canes yearly; follow specific pruning methods for floricanes vs. primocanes.
Harvest when berries are fully colored and detach easily from the central core (receptacle).

name: Almonds
title: How to Grow Almonds
overview: A deciduous tree that needs a Mediterranean climate (mild winters, hot summers); requires cross-pollination.
steps: Plant dormant bare-root trees in winter or early spring.
Plant two different varieties for adequate cross-pollination.
Requires full sun and deep, well-drained loam.
Water deeply during the spring and summer, especially as nuts fill.
Prune to maintain shape and encourage air circulation; remove water sprouts.
Treat for common pests like navel orangeworm and scale.
Harvest when the hull splits open (hull split); dry nuts before shelling.

name: Quinoa
title: How to Grow Quinoa
overview: A resilient, cool-to-warm season grain crop; can handle poor soils and drought.
steps: Direct-sow $\frac{1}{4}$ in deep in early spring, spacing 10-18 in apart.
Prefers full sun and is adapted to marginal or sandy soils.
Requires minimal water; overwatering can reduce seed production.
Minimal fertilization is needed; may benefit from a small amount of phosphorus/potassium.
Weed control is critical during the first 6 weeks of growth.
Harvest when the leaves have dropped, and the seed heads are hard and the plant is dry.
The seed must be threshed and often washed to remove saponins.

name: Celery
title: How to Grow Celery
overview: A moisture-loving, cool-season crop that needs consistent water and rich soil; difficult for beginners.
steps: Start seeds indoors very early (10-12 weeks before last frost) as they are slow growers.
Transplant 10-12 in apart in full sun or light shade; needs a trench in hot climates.
Must have absolutely consistent moisture; never let the soil dry out.
Fertilize heavily with balanced fertilizer every 2 weeks.
Blanching (covering the stems to keep them white) improves flavor.
Harvest outer stalks individually or cut the entire plant at the base when fully sized.

name: Chia
title: How to Grow Chia
overview: A heat-tolerant summer annual grown for its tiny, nutrient-dense seeds.
steps: Direct-sow seeds $\frac{1}{4}$ in deep after the last spring frost; thin plants to 18-24 in apart.
Requires a warm-to-hot climate and full sun; can tolerate poor soils.
Water sparingly; highly drought-tolerant after establishment.
Does not require heavy fertilization; avoid excess nitrogen.
Primarily grown in large fields, but suitable for small-scale garden plots.
Harvest when the flowers dry and the seed heads shatter easily.

name: Rhubarb
title: How to Grow Rhubarb
overview: A cold-tolerant perennial vegetable grown for its tart, edible stalks (leaves are poisonous).
steps: Plant crowns in early spring, ensuring the growing point is at soil level.
Plant 3-4 ft apart in a full-sun site with very rich, well-drained soil.
Water deeply during dry spells; use a thick layer of compost/manure yearly.
Do not harvest during the first two years to allow the crown to establish.
Cut flower stalks immediately to direct energy back into the roots.
Harvest stalks by pulling or twisting them off at the base (do not use a knife).

name: Flax
title: How to Grow Flax
overview: Grown for its fiber (linen) or its seeds (linseed/flaxseed).
steps: Direct-sow $\frac{1}{4}$–$\frac{1}{2}$ in deep in early spring; plant densely for fiber, or more spaced for seed.
Prefers a full-sun location with deep, fertile, well-drained soil.
Requires consistent moisture, especially during the early growth phase.
Fertilize based on soil test; avoid excessive nitrogen which can cause lodging (falling over).
Weed control is essential, as the plants are not competitive early on.
Harvest for seed when the seed capsules are golden and brittle; for fiber when the lower third of the stem is yellow.

name: Mustard
title: How to Grow Mustard Greens
overview: A fast-growing, cool-season leafy green with a pungent flavor; tolerates light frost.
steps: Direct-sow 1 in deep, 6–8 in apart, in early spring or late summer.
Choose a full-sun to partial-shade location; shade prevents bolting in warm weather.
Requires rich, well-drained soil; side-dress with nitrogen every 3–4 weeks.
Keep soil constantly moist to encourage rapid, tender growth.
Scout for flea beetles; use row covers if infestation is heavy.
Harvest by picking individual outer leaves or cutting the entire plant at the base.
Bolt quickly in hot weather, making leaves bitter.

name: Sorghum
title: How to Grow Sorghum
overview: A drought-tolerant grain and forage crop; requires high heat and is often used as a rotation crop.
steps: Direct-sow 1 in deep after the soil is warm and the danger of frost has passed.
Plant in rows 30–40 in apart; thin to 4–6 in spacing between plants.
Requires full sun and well-drained soil; very tolerant of heat and dry conditions.
Fertilize based on soil test; typically needs nitrogen similar to corn.
Weed control is critical in the early stages; may require herbicides or cultivation.
Harvest when the grains are hard and dry (around 18–20% moisture).

name: Peanuts
title: How to Grow Peanuts
overview: A warm-season annual legume that forms its pods underground; requires 4-5 months of heat.
steps: Sow raw, unshelled seeds 2 in deep and 10 in apart after soil temperature reaches $65^{\circ}\text{F}$ ($18^{\circ}\text{C}$).
Plant in full sun with light, sandy, well-drained soil; add calcium if soil is poor.
The plant produces yellow flowers that send "pegs" (stalks) into the soil, where the peanuts form.
Mound soil around the base of the plant to encourage pegging.
Water consistently, especially during the flowering/pegging period.
Harvest when the leaves turn yellow and the pods feel solid (dig up the entire plant).

name: Cranberry
title: How to Grow Cranberries
overview: A low, creeping, woody perennial shrub native to North America; requires very acidic soil and a specific environment.
steps: Plant cuttings or rooted vines in spring in a prepared bed of peat and sand.
Requires full sun and a very acidic soil (pH 4.0–5.5).
Must be able to flood the area for harvesting and winter protection (though not always necessary for small-scale growing).
Water with soft, acidic water; mulch with sand every few years.
Very susceptible to pests and diseases; needs vigilant care.
Harvest in the fall when berries are deep red and fully ripe.

name: Kohlrabi
title: How to Grow Kohlrabi
overview: A fast-growing member of the cabbage family grown for its bulbous stem base.
steps: Direct-sow 1 in deep, 4–6 in apart, in early spring or mid-summer.
Plant in full sun and rich, well-drained soil; prefers cool weather.
Keep soil consistently moist; inconsistent watering makes the bulbs tough and woody.
Side-dress with compost or balanced fertilizer when the bulb starts to swell.
Protect from common cabbage pests like flea beetles and worms.
Harvest when the swollen stem base is 2–3 in in diameter; larger bulbs are often tough.

name: Fennel
title: How to Grow Fennel
overview: Grown for its crisp, anise-flavored bulb ("Florence" or "Bulb" type).
steps: Direct-sow seeds 1 in deep; thin plants to 12–18 in apart, as they dislike transplanting.
Plant in a full
